review.title: Density Estimation for Geolocation via Convolutional Mixture Density Network
review.abstract: Nowadays, geographic information related to Twitter is crucially important for fine-grained applications. However, the amount of geographic information avail- able on Twitter is low, which makes the pursuit of many applications challenging. Under such circumstances, estimating the location of a tweet is an important goal of the study. Unlike most previous studies that estimate the pre-defined district as the classification task, this study employs a probability distribution to represent richer information of the tweet, not only the location but also its ambiguity. To realize this modeling, we propose the convolutional mixture density network (CMDN), which uses text data to estimate the mixture model parameters. Experimentally obtained results reveal that CMDN achieved the highest prediction performance among the method for predicting the exact coordinates. It also provides a quantitative representation of the location ambiguity for each tweet that properly works for extracting the reliable location estimations.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This information is indispensable for various practical applications such as the early detection of earthquakes (Sakaki et al., 2010), the evaluation of dispersion of infectious diseases (Broniatowski et al., 2013) and the assessment of user behaviour during an election period (Caldarelli et al., 2014). However, application performance is strongly dependent on the number of geo-tagged tweets, which account for less than 0.5% of all tweets (Cheng et al., 2010).In order to expand the possibilities of geographical information, great efforts have been made to automatically specify the geolocation (Han et al., 2014). These studies are roughly divided into two aspects, the user level (Cheng et al., 2010; Han et al., 2014; Jurgens et al., 2015) and the measurement level (Dredze et al.).

sections.heading: 2 Related work
sections.text: Social media geolocation has been carried out on various platforms such as Facebook (Backstrom et al., 2010), Flickr (Serdyukov et al., 2009) and Wikipedia (Lieberman and Lin, 2009). Twitter geolocation, in particular, is the dominant field of all due to its availability (Han et al., 2014). Twitter geolocation methods are not limited to text information. Various information can facilitate geolocation performance, such as meta-information (time (Dredze et al., 2016) and estimated age and gender (Pavalanathan et al., 2015), social network structures (Jurgens et al., 2015; Rahimi et al., 2015) and user movements (Liu and Huang, 2016). However, many studies have attempted user-level geolocation rather than the news level. Although user-level geolocation is certainly effective for some applications, news-level geolocation supports in-depth analysis.

sections.text: In the previous section, we introduced the CNN method for the regression problem. This regression formulation is well suited to solving well-defined problems, and both the input and output correspond 1: 1. sections.text: In this section we formalize our problem and clarify our proposed effectiveness of the model.

sections.heading: 5.1 Problem setting
sections.text: This study examines CMDN performance from two perspectives. Our first experiment is to predict the geographical coordinates that each user has given based on the single tweet content.The second experiment is used to quantitatively filter out the unreliable estimate based on the probability threshold. We then remove the estimate from the lowest probability value and calculate both the mean and the mean. This indicator is correctly filtered out when the statistics are declining monotonically. sections.text: Our proposed model provides high accuracy for our experimental data. In addition, probability thresholds reveal a consistent indicator of the safety of the estimate. sections.heading: 7 Future work
sections.text: This study evaluated the performance of our proposed model, CMDN, based solely on text data. Although a purely text-based estimate is easily applicable to existing resources, we still have room for improvement in prediction performance. Twitter's Geolocation PredictionShared Task Winner, Miura et al. (2016), suggested that the unified architecture should handle multiple metadata such as user location, user description and time zone for predicting geolocations. CMDN can integrate this information in the same way. Furthermore, Liu and Huang (2016) report that the user's location strongly influences location prediction for a single tweet. For example, a routine tweet alone using text content is fundamentally unpredictable, but if the user's location is known, this information is a valuable clue for evaluating the tweet. As a future work, we plan to develop a unified architecture that could provide the movement information of a network using a recursive coordinator, as opposed to the neural coordination of the network.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: Our proposed model, CMDN, not only provided high accuracy of our experimental data, but also extracted reliable geolocalized tweets based on probability thresholds. The results show that CMDN only needs the content of the tweet message to identify its geolocation, without the need for meta-information to be processed. As a result, CMDN can help expand the fields in which geographical information applications can be used.
